segments.text: This is Fred Bass and Nancy Bass.
I don't have an office.
These are all great quotes by the way.
Have you ever had an office?
The office on the main floor that was up there was built for me 25 years ago.
It was built specifically for me.
I spent about two hours in it.
For the first year, I spent about two hours in it, and my bookkeepers just moved in and took it over.
They left me a desk for about six months, and then they took over the desk.
You decided you didn't want to be on the floor?
You have to be or you want to be?
Well, that's where I'm productive.
And do you feel the same way?
She's nodding her head in the affirmative.
So tell me where we are.
And you own this building now, right?
This is where we receive shipments of manures and quantities and stuff.
and do our processing up here and our storage.
And I'm just taking it physically through the warehouse just to show you the storage.
What would you estimate the square footage up here?
And it's packed.
There's a room there that's filled with stuff and storage.
And there's boxes blocking the aisles.
Now, most of these things are under control.
You can retrieve most of them.
One, two, three, four, five, six, seven.
So I see there's more.
I know, but I'm just counting with the red here.
Is this largely review?
Why is so much inventory essential?
I can't answer the question.
That's why you've got to have such a big spread.
of books to keep people around.
And I think that you've got to grab the bargain that you want.
Grab the bargain?
Yeah, but a lot of, you've got an MBA, Nancy.
Is it costing you money to store so much inventory?
It is.
That's why we want to open up another floor and get as much stuff as we can.
because especially the New York rental market.
That was the theory, wasn't it, when you opened up the Fulton Street store?
Fulton Street is 15,000 square feet.
And we figured that at least we can get rid of part of the 10th floor.
This is unbelievable.
Yeah.
I think the books just multiply.
Hold this for me.
Sure.
I'm going to take a few pictures.
Don't worry about it.
I'm just wandering around with you.
The books just multiply at night.
It's really nothing to do with us.
Don't you think?
I don't even want to take you down there because the thing is so... Who does all the buying?
Do you do the buying?
I do most of the buying over the counter when I'm here, but I have backup buyers here, of course.
The remainder of buying is done by a team.
Mostly one of my men, Paul Secord, does it with a backup team from the art department and the review department.
The review does their own buying.
most of the time.
Rare Book Room does their buying, but we buy a lot of rare books on the main floor and send them upstairs.
And you move a lot of stuff, like proofs that come in and galleys.
Yeah, they come from all different departments.
So there's a lot of team buying going on here.
I essentially control the buying in the store yet.
What do you wild-ass estimate guess of what you have in terms of logging?
Two and a half million books plus.
In this location?
In this location.
Wow.
Well, you know, our slogan is eight miles of books, but it's really more like... Twelve and a half miles of books.
Yeah, but it's too hard to change the slogan at this point.
More than most libraries.
Yeah.
But physically, you can see what we have up here.
They're just, you know, the boxes are all under control.
Do you know what's in all of these places?
Yeah.
Up here, pretty much everything's under control.
And the control means that it's cataloged.
It's cataloged.
It's either in the computer or in a record index.
So the boxes are labeled, and they say the price on it, and they say how many books are in the boxes, and when they got it in with the publisher.
I'm having a major check.
Take a shot.
Let's see what gets you a better aisle.
How about the center aisle?
Or do you want boxes?
Where he can kind of like go into debt?
Do you want boxes?
The lights out now.
I love this.
It's better lit.
Oh yeah.
It's always.
I don't know if you're going to get it through there, Chad.
How many employees are?
About 185.
185 employees.
I think that's the fun of at least downstairs.
I think that some of the fun of downstairs is that, you know, it is a little chaotic, like up here in the warehouse, too, where we're getting in all these books all the time.
We're getting in lots, and Fred's pricing them, and we're getting in all the new books.
So it almost, it's such a different feel from any other place because you can, the books get priced right away, and they're out right away.
So it's, and you can see, but you can watch him buying it right from, you know, where you're buying the books from.
Your father says he has a book madness.
Do you have that as well?
Yeah.
We used to see boxes in the aisle.
We used to see the boxes piled in the aisle.
Those are just shipments that came in temporarily.
Wherever I go, I go and visit the bookstores.
I was just in Bucks County, and I visited bookstores there.
And I bought, even buy books all the time from other stores.
You mentioned the last thing you shared in English.
And I go to the flea markets.
When I went out there, I bought a whole lot of books from there, too.
I'm always doing that.
You go to the homes and the people who work for you and their homes look like this.
Oh, exactly like this.
It's amazing.
Pick up one.
What were you saying about that?
Whenever I go to the homes of any of the employees or the managers, they look exactly like the Strand.
There's books piled up on the floors and on the shelves everywhere.
It's a little bit disorganized.
And there's very little room for furniture and for living.
It's all books.
Does that mean that you attract?
Yes.
Oh, wait, there's a little more I want to show them here yet.
The type of employees love books, and they
They loved collecting things, and they loved old books, especially.
And that's across the board.
I'm so surprised, every single one of them.
This used to be our old rare book department.
Yeah, so now the three rooms are also filled up with remainders and processing of things we're doing and stuff.
You know, stuff I can't resist.
They're full leather and half leather books.
They might have those for the next 10 to 15 years.
So I bought them for a long time because I get constant calls from these things.
And they're all classic titles that we'll never go out of.
For instance, why don't you just read a couple off Nancy?
I see the background by Dr. Daphne de Maurier.
The Iliad, The Odyssey, Copperfield.
Mary Shelley has heard that the price, look at the price.
Wow, $5.95, that's the strand place.
And does it move pretty well?
Oh, yeah, yeah.
At that price it does.
And that's nicely illustrated in a box.
And the same with the Franklins.
The Franklins are half leather, books are $15.
And to think that you go into a regular bookstore and you pay like $25 for just any kind of a hardbound book that says nothing, you can get classic leather books for $15 here.
Excuse me.
This is really the heart of the business up here.
Well, I don't want to say that.
Would you say that, that this is the heart of the business?
I think it's downstairs with the used, yeah.
But it's a combination.
Yeah, it's a part of the team.
Do you have an idea of how many people on average walk in?
I don't even want to know.
All right.
Yeah, yeah.
That's really great.
Now, when you were going to the University of Wisconsin, did you plan to come into that?
Yeah, I always did.
Did you?
I always wanted to, yeah.
Do you have any siblings?
Because I think, yeah, I do.
I have an older brother who's not interested.
But I think that the reason why I wanted to is because I know how much my father loves it, so that was always reflected, and I thought this would be the greatest thing to do.
I mean, I tried other things.
I worked for Esson for a while.
I mean, I did a lot of small.
I worked as an intern and worked in an advertising company.
For Exxon, I was a business consultant.
I had a sales and territory service station, and I kind of was in between with Exxon.
I really enjoyed it.
I really liked the gasoline station owners.
So you actually did try other things before coming in here?
Yeah.
Or was this for experience?
For experience to do this.
And you're a partner with your father now, is that right?
Do you have a formal title?
Do you have titles here?
Well, I'm a part owner, too.
I mean, he's got the majority, but he should.
Well, would you say that you were motivated to come into this business as much because it is a tradition?
If you weren't here to assume the mantle that it would be the disappearance of an institution?
I don't think so.
I mean, it really depends on who bought it, so I'm having a hard time kind of projecting it, but I would think definitely if a corporation bought it, it definitely would not be the same.
It would be, well, Barnes & Noble's opened up that annex, that used book annex, and that failed miserably.
They lost lots and lots of money.
I'm sorry.
Hi.
Do you want us to go around, or can you unblock that a little bit?
Oh, OK.
OK, thanks.
Yeah.
I don't know.

I think it's always, you know, you always lose something, too, if somebody doesn't have an interest in a business, where it's not personal, where they're not here all the time, because my father and I are here almost all the time.
So there's always a, there's basically a boss here.
Yeah.
I think that's important to you.
I think it is, yeah.
I mean, it's really hard work, too, with the amount of time that you spend here.
I mean, but it's not such hard work if you really love it, though.
You know, some of them don't want you to,
I don't touch it.
I want you to remember that.
It's something you want to talk about.
You introduced this book rental.
I'm interested in talking about that.
I'm going to have a chapter in this talk about institutional libraries and how books still matter.
Believe it or not, in this technological paradigm shift that they're going on.
Are you noticing a slowdown in acquisitions from colleges?
No, no.
No, our library business is still very healthy, and they're very active.
And they come to us mainly because of price.
They save a lot of money.
We have the books, but the price is very important to a lot of them.
They're spending so much money on technology, they've got to save some money on it.
Watch your staff.
It's a little hot.
Is this a traditional area?
What's that?
Is this something you just noticed?
The library is traveling.
And we're talking academic libraries.
Academic libraries and public libraries.
Would you have a ballpark guess of how many libraries you do business with on a regular basis?
Thousands.
Thousands?
All over the world.
Hundreds are actors.
but occasionally thousands, yeah.
So what happens?
Do you think that they send you a list of newly published books and try and have you fill them?
Oh, I'll explain.
We'll explain later on.
I just want to show you the madness of this operation, because most of these, not all of them, are new libraries that we acquired.
These are private-type libraries or individual libraries?
Maybe your questions are... 10th floor.
These are part of the Hilton Head.
We pick more.
We send the annex.
We send some of them as we can.
Do you want to put, like, annex instead of a label?
Oh, yeah.
We just have to mark these off.
Mary Shelley Frankenstein books.
Are you showing me downstairs?
Yeah, extra storage for them.
Yeah, but how many did you buy?
Yeah, that's whole block.
I couldn't say none for that.
Most of these things here are collections of books they've bought, but I haven't gotten to yet.
So there are estates and things that you've got?
Libraries that Marvin has bought, or I've bought, and they're in storage up there.
So there's a very good possibility that there's some rare books in here.
Oh, there's a lot.
There's a whole... I would say there's at least 2,000 boxes for the rare book department to process.
That they're here.
That they'll never get to.
Don't say that.
You don't know what's in there.
Well, we'll let Marvin retire until he does them.
He doesn't do them anymore, so he's just terrible.
Up here are still... Lonnie?
Is this open?
How old is this building?
What was it originally?
An office building?
Manufacturing.
Manufacturing.
Bill?
We officially describe ourselves as being in the East Village, is that right?
Well, that's the village.
I'm not going to drag you through.
There's three rooms back there.
There's two big rooms back there and all this whole stuff.
The 10th floor is just filled with boxes.
I took it over temporarily about four years ago.
Just a little spot up there I took from the landlord before I bought the building.
Little by little I filled it.
So where did you keep this stuff before you acquired the building?
I just keep multiplying.
But everything is on site, though.
You don't have any other warehouses?
No.
No, I've got 81.
What's wrong?
Oh, they're working on it.
Do we have maps this way?
Um, we can show them that.
Do you have maps?
Mm-hmm.
All right, we'll go down the street.
You don't see them up there, I think.
Nice, nice.
Need the idea.
Uh, this is celebrating, though.
We're working on it.
What?
I think it's not based on the payment.
Oh, okay.
All right, let's go down to the back.
There was a piece in Fortune magazine, and I can't say I read the whole thing, but it was about some guy who moved from here doing that piece.
Yeah, it was with Capitol.
Yeah.
Yeah.
He's in this book.
Well, it's right.
The boxes go way back there, too.
You want to see it?
This isn't Doyle up here, huh?
No, that's not Doyle.
Is that a cutter?
No, this is.
You've actually gone through this.
Unbelievable.
I've never seen anything like this.
I've seen places filled with books, but I've never seen places filled with boxes.
These are things we've got to get through.
I'm sorry, what?
We bought a library of 20,000 books.
From a customer of mine from way back.
All handpicked by him.
Probably many of them bought here.
I don't know where he's going to put it, but... Lonnie, Lonnie, this is Nicholas Basman's book.
That book is really famous.
Did you do tours and things?
Yeah.
Wow.
I'm still doing stuff.
I'm giving the keynote address at the A.B.
Bookman's weekly thing out in Colorado Springs.
Wow.
Did you do TV, too?
I was on, you know, the Brian Lamb book, Book Notes?
Sure.
I'm in there.
Wow.
My interviewer's in there.
He picked my interviewer and put me in Storytellers, which is very nice.
Oh, if we, uh, the, uh, Poulter's going to bring out the owl edition, finally, of my book in March.
Yeah?
Oh, that's great.
With a new preface.
I'm going to write a 4,000-word update.
Of disease?
Just, you know, things that have happened in three years.
Bloomberg is out of jail and back in jail again.
Carter Burden died.
You know, his library went to the Morgan.
Chef Louis died.
Haskell Norman not only died, but his library is one of the biggest sales at auction of the life.
So that kind of stuff.
And Aaron Lansky, the Yiddish Book Center, finally opened in Hampshire.
So there's some nice, cute things.
And it proves the essential theme of the book is the cycle of books.
You just mentioned 20,000 books that you bought that are coming back here.
Probably 10,000 of them came here.
Originally, the guy was a customer of mine 30 years ago.
He disappeared on me for the last 10 years, but he moved up to Connecticut, and suddenly he's had to move, and he didn't want to move the book.
So did these 20,000 books come out of an apartment?
No, it's a house.
Out of a house.
Wow.
Which is really great.
It's all this recycling, you know, the books.
They just keep coming back, and people can read them, and then they can... I know the picture you have is a little terrific, but this is kind of cool, too.
Let's give me another one.
Okay.
That's great.
Excellent.
Thank you.
I like it.
I use my own pictures in my books, too.
You know, you were asking me about, you know, I don't know if you've been to a lot of employees' homes, but it's exactly like the store, where it's books everywhere, and I was saying that.
Now, my home, on the other hand, is just the opposite of the store.
Why is that?
I have, um, I bring books home all the time.
I read them, and then I return them right away to the store.
Because I want, I want people, it's a good book, I want people to read it.
When did you start working with your father?
I was about 13 years old.
I used to come down and sleep.
So you've always been in the business?
Were you like your daughter?
Did you go after school?
No, I worked after school.
The only time I tried to... Well, I had a few other jobs, you know, small jobs after school.
like a runner for Joey Gold Theatre Ticket Service, which I made a lot of money at as a kid.
Has he seen the office?
Huh?
Has he seen the third floor or the office?
He knows the third floor.
He goes up the real book room all the time, so he knows that part of the operation.
They told my wife and daughters if they get lost today to Carl Craig.
He'll know where you are.
He goes down on a conveyor belt.
Shrink wrap.
Shipping.
This is not for here.
Is this for here?
Yeah, it's here.
Sorry?
Okay.
That's Marvin's office right there.
And this is the clinical department.
which will soon practically disappear.
So, we're now in the... This is the computer room, and this is where we do our desktop publishing.
We're going to just leave that there, don't worry about it.
And we'll go on a... You don't mind if it's...
Episodic, I mean, if we went around.
Whatever you like.
Tell me a little bit, if you can give me a little chronology.
When did your father start the business?
It started in 1927.
You're going to have all that in the papers for yourself.
So you're going to have a background there.
I started working for them after school when I was 13, 14 years old.
And I continued until I got out of college.
Then I went into the Army for two years.
Where'd you go to college?
I went to Brooklyn College.
Sorry?
Were you planning?
I mean, did you always know that you'd be coming into this business?
No, no, I didn't.
I know I liked it, but I didn't know I would be here.
Where was your dad located?
Well, we were starving when I was going to school.
And, you know, it was a very tough city.
Was your father one of these 4th Avenue booksellers?
Originally, the store was on 4th Avenue.
The original store was on Astro Place.
And then we moved to 4th Avenue.
And for a period until about 25, no, I'm told about 40 some odd years ago, we were on 4th Avenue and we lost our lease.
And we were one of the first stores to move off 4th Avenue.
You were one of the first?
First stores.
How many were left at that?
There were about 48 stores on 4th Avenue.
At a time.
28 stores and warehouses and offices that, you know, booksellers that operated out of office.
And the gentleman who handles rare books for you, Marvin Mondland, has been working on a history.
He was working on 4th Avenue.
He also, for as long as I've known him, has been working on a history.
And at some point I'm going to talk to Marvin about that, because I'd love that you can get some quotes about the tradition from which you emerged.
What happened?
What happened?
What happened for 4th Avenue?
Yeah, what happened?
Okay.
The standard reason, Fourth Avenue, the standard accepted reason that Fourth Avenue disappeared by everybody is that the rents went up and were too high for the youth book business.
I've been challenging that right along.
I said the real reason Fourth Avenue disappeared was that the 48, some of the 40-some-odd booksellers there were all very strong, self-centered individuals who kept all their knowledge to themselves.
They didn't teach anybody.
and only two sons of booksellers went into the business.
That was Donald Weiser, W-E-I-S-C-R.
What was the name of that?
It was Weiser's bookstore.
Donald went into it, and now he's an occult book publisher out of Maine.
So he no longer has a retail store.
Yeah, in fact, his retail store closed about five years ago.
And his retail store in Fort Abdon didn't specialize in a cult, too?
Well, he was specialized in a cult, but he was a second-hand bookseller.
He actually had a good gimmick that you enjoyed.
He put the books out on tables, and he had a succession of about 10-12 tables.
And every day, practically every day, the books would be moved to the back.
as fresh stuff came in, and the books in the back would be marked down and put up front until they were down to practically 35 cents each.
Very interesting.
But that was the way they operated, continuous rotation.
You mentioned that, was this endemic to the species, that they kept all the information to themselves?
It was just, they were strong individuals, including my dad.
Were they largely Jewish?
Yeah, mostly Jewish.
And was this
a trade that they learned from many of the immigrants?
Did they come here with this still?
No, I think a lot of them were American-born.
You only have a chapter in this book on the Jewish booksellers, by the way.
Look, I think Martin will give you more information on their religion, but I can't remember the background.
Yeah, they all came out with Depression people.
I mean, Argusy used to be on the book.
I didn't know that.
Way, way back.
But we were the first, one of the first ones to leave for it that year, and we moved over to Broadway.
And this is what's going to be interesting for you.
And one of the reasons we were successful on Broadway, which was not a book tour, which was off the beaten track of Hook Park, it was more street track.
We got off a dead street onto an active street.
Do you think if you hadn't moved from 4th Avenue to here that you'd still be in business?
Do you think you wouldn't?
Well, it'd still be in business.
I don't think it would be successful.
It wouldn't be the business that it is today.
Yeah, it wouldn't be what it is.
But it was just, there was so much more traffic and more people.
To go back, everybody talks about it.
It's true.
I mean, I'm there to echo.
I want to backtrack.
We left out the park.
There were strong individuals that didn't impart anything.
They all got old.
and fade it away.
They couldn't face the doubling of rice.
They couldn't face the increase in expense.
You know, they were too old and tired, so they just faded away.
Can you think of a few names?
No, there was Stammer, there was
But I mean, you're right, if the rents were increased, then they would find another part of town to move into and make that a bookman.
We went from 4th Avenue, where we were paying $110 a month rent.
And it had just been increased, so, you know, $110 to Broadway and 12th, where our rent was $400.
Everybody thought we were crazy.
We were scared.
Before I bought the building, my landlord was getting a check for me every month for $55,000.
So I went from $110 a month to $55,000.
I bought it in about a year and a half.
And I understand you're planning actually to redesign.
We have designs to take over another floor, a second floor, and open up the retail space.
So we would have four floors of retail?
Yeah.
Are you going to change the nature of the business?
Just expand all the sections that we have, make it a little more user-friendly, and get more hard books on this planet.
We've got stores on the 10th floor and the 5th floor.
How would you describe this bookstore?
Is it a second-hand bookstore?
Essentially, it's a second-hand bookstore.
Tell me about that.
You basically initiated that here, didn't you?
And I've read in various stories that this is a teaser.
Is this something that you make money on?
Well, we have to make money on it because the volume is so big.
But we don't make a lot of money.
What amazes me is that you buy everything.
The problem is we have to buy everything, and we get stuck with a tremendous amount of material.
That just doesn't even sell to half price.
But that's quite a compact you make with these customers.
That's the only way I can get the books.
We buy them all across the books.
The only time we won't do that is when we find out that there are lots of new things.
And I think that's essential.
It's a good thing.
Do you sell a lot of these reviewers' books to institutional libraries?
Yes.
As a rough estimate, how many reviewers would you say?
Hundreds.
Hundreds.
And all over the country.
It took us many, many years to do this.
And of course, one, I think,
You maintain confidential... Absolutely confidential with all people we deal with.
And how long has... I don't want the world to know who I'm dealing with because I don't want competition on that.
And you basically have Claire Fields in New York doing this, wouldn't you say?
More or less, yeah.
I'm sorry to be jumping around here.
I would like to get a little more detail on the institutional stuff that you did.
We have a lot of librarians coming into business.
They're trips to New York, but they're in New York.
They come back and they select the books.
That's one way.
We do a lot through our catalogs.
We produce lists from the libraries.
And then many libraries just order from us a place where we go blanket orders.
any books that they're ordering before they order them from the publisher or the distributor.
I did an interview with a woman who just opened a new university library in Florida.
It's not even a year old.
It's a year old.
Next one.
She's the one who got the books from Uppsala out in New Jersey, $450,000.
She was a steal.
She left the whole college library.
But she said to buy a new academic book, the average price is $51 a book.
The published price is probably up there, yeah.
And so she was trying to explain what a great deal it was.
Now, assuming that to be the case, the institutions that do business with you are getting a pretty good deal, right?
Oh, absolutely.
The ones that do it, yeah.
But the librarians are too lazy to do it.
That's what it is.
Oh, they have a fixed budget.
Well, if they have a fixed budget, they need to come to us.
So you would say you do business with hundreds of librarians all over the country?
Ivy League schools, would you say?
Some Ivy League schools, some in the film.
Are you at liberty to name any of these?
That's fine.
My feelings aren't direct, but any question in your own hands, don't blame me for asking me.
Well, our customer list is confidential.
That's fine.
But with all this talk about paradigm shifts away from print culture to electronic culture, you personally have not seen a reduction?
Our sales have gone up continuously throughout this whole time.
And our sales have gone up with the Barnes & Noble's competition there, too.
Barnes & Noble has a superstore five blocks north of me, on Union Square North.
Four-story, dealing with second-hand books?
No, new books, singles.
But I mean, they draw customers, and then they've got another superstore, five blocks more.
And then their main store is still at 18th and 6th.
18th and 10th, which is five blocks, six blocks a year.
So I get surrounded by them, and I say, as I continue, I say, go ahead.
You don't do the kinds of things that, you know, Powell's is it, or the tattered cover, I mean, they're nice, they have readings, and they have authors.
You don't have to do that, do you?
We don't have the space of the time, really.
But would you do it if you have the space?
We've done a couple of them.
We find that they're good time consuming.
And then they interfere with our customers coming into the store.
So I think that we're just really focused on the book.
And forget about the fixtures and everything like that.
That's our coffee bars.
That's our thing, is books.
The best prices, the best quality of books, the getting the volume in, trying to help customers, and that's it.
I will probably use this quote certainly in the bibliopiece.
Because I've already written a lot of Berto Leibold.
I've read the Leibold piece.
Oh, sorry.
That won't be another book.
He said, my wife and I visited him in Milan in November.
He said, this is his favorite place in New York.
Oh, yeah.
He comes in there all the time.
Barnard.
How does that happen?
How does it happen that you have people?
And he's just... Sometimes he finds such a variety of material there.
That's what it is.
And it's always fresh.
There's always something new.
So you can walk in here and see different things.
You indicated that to that?
One of his books is probably the biggest bestseller we've ever had, which is Shadows of Hyper-Reality.
He told me about that.
Absolutely incredible.
Yeah, because I talked to him about some of the themes that he writes about.
